The first day of school always involves a mountain of effort, planning and dedication. This year was the culmination of so much more thought and time than past school years that it has felt like a miracle today to see the wheels in motion. Students arrived and found their rooms, wore their masks, figured out their bathrooms, explored the new outdoor classrooms around the campus and engaged with each other in meaningful ways. Here are some pictures to help families see what it looked like!
Thank you to the volunteers who dedicated dozens of hours to make desks, move furniture out, set up barriers and sheds and create the outdoor spaces. Notice the little wooden tables (45 of them in K-2!) built by Jeff Kern, Howard Hedstrom and Jonathon Hedstrom to help us meet our individualized furniture needs- shared tables and desks had to go. See everyone tomorrow!

For further details on the 3 modes of instruction, please see the full contingency plan on our website.

Now that the learning mode has been decided, there is much to do! Please consider joining us for a work day on Sunday August 23 to move the many small tables and desks required for a socially distanced classroom, and put our cozy-spot furniture into storage. Pete will be here all day, so stop by for any time you can spare from 9-4. Let Pete know you're coming with an email to peter.james@greatexpectationsschool.com

Planning your garden? GES will be ready with your plants!

The Annual GES Plant Sale will be happening in a big way this May. We trialed less plant varieties last year, and we heard the community feedback that they wanted the varieties they've come to love!

Looking for a little early interaction with some soil? Plant sale volunteers are still doing much of the transplanting and watering... just not together on Saturdays :) To set up a time to come in, contact Alisa or Erik at
plant.sale@greatexpectationsschool.com

From Alisa "We will have lots of plants and may spread the sale out over a few weeks. We will definitely be bursting at the seams with tomatoes-: Slicers: Glacier, Cosmonaut Volkov, Cherokee Purple. Cherry tomatoes: Sun gold, Be my Baby. Grape tomatoes: Juliet.
Other notables this year are an abundance of pansies and wave petunias, and lots of herbs for the herb garden, as well as many of the usual flowers and veggies."

Adult lunches are 5$ and include one serving of the hot entree, and soup, sandwich & salad bar. DF/ GF options are available with notice. Purchase tickets from Lesa at the front desk.

Thanks so much to the Great Lunch program for their efforts providing really fresh food we are excited to eat!

GES Plant Sale transplanting work begins this Saturday February 22 from 10-1! We need you to come help plant seedlings! This year, transplanting hosts are here for just 6 Saturdays, and we're asking families from different classrooms to help with each of them. This Saturday we're inviting families of Wolves, Lynx and Otters, as well as all interested school community members.

Last year's sale was a necessarily smaller plant sale, as there were not enough volunteers to help with the dozens of hours of transplanting work. This year our sights are set on a full scale plant sale again, with all of the varieties and abundance we've had historically.

This is a vital part of GES, with students learning about organic gardening, seeding, transplanting and caring for plants while producing thousands of plants used by the community. Come join us!

If you can make it, let us know: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/904094fa5ae29aafc1-gesplant

Thank you everyone who helped make this fun tradition come alive!

post_text: Welcome to our 15th year of shaping hearts and minds, one child at a time! The first few weeks of class has already blown by. GES practices The First Six Weeks, part of the Responsive Classroom model, in which the emphasis of classroom activity is in establishing positive language, behavioral and academic expectations, and routines that will set the stage for the rest of the year. This may sound like easier work, but many students will still seem exhausted by learning and practicing the new expectations. This is also the time in which students and adults in the classroom are spending more time sharing about themselves and building their relationships. If you're feeling concerned about the lack of homework, by mid-October you can expect to see more academic pursuits picking up. Here are pictures from the 1st week and annual Fall Beach Day, during which the entire K-8 school community gathers at the beach for a lot of multi-age activities... or just resting at the beach!

post_text: The Beavers (2nd grade) and Fawns (1st grade) took a trip together this Fall to Grand Portage, visiting the Grand Portage National Monument and Heritage Center together. Students visited an archaeological dig site and learned about what earlier inhabitants of the area used- old bullets, gun parts, hand hammered nails and more. Next, they learned about the fundamentals of the Fur Trade that shaped this region- especially the beaver and the canoe. Pictured below are students in the boat house where birch bark canoes are still constructed, and visiting the historic Fort where they very eagerly felt the pelts of a dozen local animals, and learned how beavers became hats. After a picnic, the group looked at the Ojibwe traditions, seen below inside a birch bark wigwam, and going through each step of processing wild rice (parching, dancing and winnowing). Thank you to the Anishinabe Fund, whose grant made it possible for each GES classroom to plan a regular visit to the Heritage Center!

post_text: Welcome back to the school! Meet the new orchard across the street, a collaboration between the Law Enforcement Center, the Master Gardeners and County Extension Office, Ray Block, Erik Hahn and an anonymous donor. The orchard contains 120 apple trees, cherry trees and has room for grapes, blackberries and more. We are thrilled to be included. Erik will work with classroom teachers to integrate studying the orchard's growth into Science and classroom activities. When harvests begin, the food will tie into the school's food and nutrition program, providing fruit for school lunches. We also plan to do some service learning, getting the fruit out into other community programs. The fence is to keep out the deer, not the students! :)

post_text: The Ga Ga Pit is ready! Thank you to our 2 middle school students,( & their teacher and parents), who wanted to design and build a Ga Ga Pit for the school as part of their math unit. The concept began last fall, when the students realized what a hit Ga Ga was during their weekly YMCA visits. They asked for donations to buy the materials, and have nearly reached their goal. For those of you new to the game, kids K-8 are loving Ga Ga and can tell you all about it. Imagine dodge ball, but the ball has to hit you below the knee. This makes the game a bit less dangerous, and requires more skill. The kids are still about $85 short of their goal, so if you think you can contribute any amount to the cause, please send it on to our Front Office.
